Yes: if Y pays A via Ripple, ownership is recorded in the path. If Y pays A outside of Ripple, the $ system is what recorded ownership.
Note that Ripple can only do that *because* the currencies being transferred already have global consensus - a requirement of a currency.
The difference is in Bitcoin, X pays Y something that A and B might accept later. In Ripple, A->B and X->Y can be different currencies.
Remember that in Ripple the focus is on payments of other currencies, not an in-system token.
The original Ripple system took the opposite approach - you needed to have consensus with your peers, but non-peers were ~irrelevant to you.
What do you mean by "Bitcoiners" there? What do you mean by "interact"?
Yes, Bitcoin needs global consensus because it's a store of value. A payment system OTOH doesn't necessarily need global consensus.
Ripple's P2P "digital hawala" just needs consensus between peers, not global consensus.
